text:
This is EE380. This is the second to last
of the talks for Spring 2023.

Our speaker today
is Charles Tahan. He's at the Office of
Science and Technology Policy

in Washington, DC. And he is responsible for
designing quantum computers

and coordinating the
National Quantum Initiative.

Quantum computers are thought by
some to be, well, like fusion.

It's going to be the
best thing in 50 years. And it will next year be
the best thing in 50 years.

But that's not true. Quantum computers
are real things and are practical in
some instances today.

And I think we're going
to have a major interest

in additional
quantum computer work because well, it's one
of the things that we do.

Charles, thank you
very much for coming and I'm going to just leave
the channel open here for you.

All right. Well, thank you, Dennis. I gave this seminar back when I
was starting my career so it's

nice to be back N years later. OK. So [CHUCKLES] back to
the scheduled program.

My name is Charlie Tahan. I'm the Assistant Director here
for Quantum Information Science

at OSTP. I'm also Director of the
National Quantum Coordination Office. I'm on detail from the
Laboratory for Physical Sciences

which is the research
physics division of NSA

located at the University
of Maryland, College Park. I just like to
start all the talks I give with this slide
which says basically,

there's many ways to
contribute to your field. In my career, I've done a
lot of different things. I've worked in academia.

I've worked as a
consultant at DARPA. I've led research teams
in the government,

have been a technical
program manager. And now I'm doing policy in the
National Quantum Coordination

Office. So there's many different
ways to move science forward and I just like to
highlight that for people

may be coming from school and
haven't realized that yet. And I'm happy to take
any questions at the end

about different pathways.  It's been a big year for
quantum policy in the US.

President Biden signed two
presidential directives back
in May, which is pretty unusual. It has never happened before. It probably won't happen again.

The first was an executive order
to create the National Quantum Initiative Advisory
Committee as a Presidential

Committee to advise
him, and Congress, and the leaders of the
agencies on the NQI programs.

The second was the national
security memorandum which is very much like an
executive order on the risks

of quantum computers
and moving the country to post-quantum cryptography. So I'm going to tell you a
little bit about those things

and the whole policy behind
the National Quantum Initiative

today, as well as give
you an example of how one agency, my agency
is implementing

some of these aspects
of the strategy. I'll just start off by saying
my field is quantum computing.

That's primarily where
I've spent the last 20 years of my research career. This is my favorite
picture of the last year.

This is President Biden
visiting IBM Research

on the tour of New York and
the various fabs up there. Of course, it had to be
copied from somewhere.

This is a picture of me. [CHUCKLES] I'm just
being facetious copying the president
when I was visiting

Fermilab earlier in the year. Let me just remind you why
quantum information matters.

If you think about all
technology we use today, primarily it's based
on our understanding

of how physical devices work. We call how matter behaves at
the microscopic level quantum

mechanics. Those are the rules that govern
how very small things behave. In our first foray into taking
our understanding of that

and applying it technology
resulted in things like clocks,

the transistor, imaging
devices like MRIs, Magnetic Resonance Imagers.

With those physical devices,
then we built abstractions. We developed information theory.

The 0's and 1's,
the language that lets us design operating
systems, and compilers,

and programming languages. And all that has worked
tremendously well if you think about how impactful
information technology has
been on our lives. But it's wrong.

The information
theory that really governs all the
technology you use now,

the idea of Turing machines
and so on, it works but it's not complete.

And that realization which
really began in the 1980s that if we really want to design
information technology based

on how the universe
really works, we really need to incorporate
quantum mechanics. That is what has led to this new
field called quantum information

science. And so very crudely,
just to remind you,

quantum 1.0, the
technologies that were built off of the first
50 years of quantum mechanics

since it was discovered
in the early 1900s, that technology is based on
really a couple simple facts

about how the world works. One that matter is quantized
into atoms, into photons,

into electrons. And two, that these
systems, these particles

have discrete energy levels. And from that, you can
design things like lasers. You can think about one electron
going through a transistor

and so on. And that led to
electronics, photonics, and many other technologies. Quantum information science is
about taking the second order

effects of quantum information
theory, the stuff we ignored over that first
almost 100 years or so

and trying to make better
information technology out of that. So quantum superposition,
that a particle can be

in two places at the same time. Quantum entanglement,
that particles can be correlated
over great distances

and need to be treated
as a single object. Quantum measurements, that when
you look at a quantum object

or measure it, it
collapses to one of the basis states or
the classical states

that it's in superposition of. These things can let
you potentially design new types of sensors, new
types of computers and networks

that allow you to couple
those sensors and computers. That's really what quantum
information science technology

is about, trying to use those
second order properties. And it really is a foundational
shift in information technology.

It is something to
be excited about. Because we have a
few examples where

we know or we extremely
strongly suspect, believe that it
will be dramatic--

quantum version of
certain technologies will be dramatically better
or different than the best thing you can do classically.

So first just for
science, if you want to explore
quantum mechanics,

we know that you can't perfectly
simulate multiple large quantum

systems past 50 or so qubits. We can stretch it
out to 100 if you

make a lot of approximations. But beyond that, we just can't
do it on a classical computer.

So if you had a quantum
computer bigger than that, there's a lot of science likely
that we're going to learn.

Two, the first killer
app, Cryptanalysis, this is picture
of Peter Shor, who

was at Bell Labs at the time. He came up with an
algorithm that could only run on a quantum
computer that happens

to break the dominant
mathematical hard problem that

underlies our public
key cryptography system. So this is called Shor's
Quantum Algorithm.

We have done a lot of work on
that algorithm over the last 20 years. And at present
state of the art, we

think it requires around
10 million qubits. It's fairly high quality
to build a quantum machine

that large that could break
public key cryptography.

So Cryptanalysis. And then chemistry. Because the universe operates by
the rules of quantum mechanics,

when it calculates the
properties of chemical, or chemical dynamics, or
materials, it's using reality.

So if we could build a digital
simulator of quantum, a quantum computer, there's
a lot of evidence

that if it's big enough, we
can do things that we just can't calculate classically. And there are many
other things that

are a little bit
more speculative but these three alone
are concrete examples

where a large enough
computer is going to do things that a classical
technologies can never do.

And so there's reason
for excitement. I'm going to start by telling
you about the National Quantum

Initiative, and what
my job is, and what we're doing at OSTP
and across the agency

is to coordinate this activity. First, the first
thing to understand

is the United States is a
very federal system in terms of R&D funding.

We operate in a kind
of a cycle of Congress

creating laws to spur investment
in certain areas, the President

and the Executive
Office of the President, all the agencies
within it, including the Office of
Management and Budgets,

OSTP, now Security
Council recommending what should be done
what kind of initiatives

or areas of technology that
the US should invest in and what should our policy be.

And then the agencies who
actually implement what the other two--

what is funded by congress. And they have their own
missions, each very different.

They have their own models of
funding, each very different. And that system together makes
the federal side of R&D science

investment in the US. And that sits within
the greater ecosystem of industry on the
one hand and academia

and the national
and federal labs on the other which work
together to actually advance

research and development. And this is very
much true of quantum. And over the years there have
been a few national level

initiatives that congress has
enacted, the latest of which

is the Artificial Intelligence
Coordination Activity.

Before that was the quantum one. Before that the National
Nanotechnology Initiative,

climate change, and so on. The National Quantum Initiative
Act passed at the end of 2018.

It was really the culmination
of two decades of investment from federal agencies in helping
to create this new field.

And I think a reflection of a
growing interest from industry

and investments from industry
to explore the potential. So Congress passed this act.

It was signed by the
president at the end of 2018. It did a few things. It created my office, the
National Quantum Coordination

Office within OSTP. The NQCO is made up of
detailees like myself

from the federal agencies
that funds most of the quantum R&D in the US, so NSF,
Department of Energy, NIST,

the National Institute of
Standards and Technology, Department of Defense which is
like a country in and of itself.

It's got DARPA and
many different-- all the service labs have
their own funding agencies. The intelligence community which
has IARPA, the Intelligence
DARPA, and LPS, and so on. So the NQCO is quite unique.

We have four to five quantum
physicist and computer scientists in the
White House you

know working to coordinate
all the programs in the NQI. Those programs consist of
National Quantum Information

Science Research Centers. So DOE was asked
to stand up five, NSF was asked to stand up
five, and the DOD and the IC

stood up or designated three
in separate legislation. So we have 13 National Quantum
Information Science Centers

which are brand new. Direct result of the NQI. Roughly the base funding for R&D
programs across all the agencies

doubled in the last
few years, which was a direct result of NQI.

NIST was asked to help industry
launch a Quantum Economic

Development Consortium, an
industry consortium for quantum that now has roughly 160
companies participating

plus professional societies
and some universities who

want to understand the
economic roadmap for quantum

technologies. It called for an advisory
committee for the NQI and so on.

So that's what the
legislation did. And the way it's
coordinated is twofold.

One is through the
coordination office. The other is through
subcommittees that are housed in the White House.

So the National Science
and Technology Council forms interagency
subcommittees which

then oversee the NQI programs. Quantum actually has
two subcommittees,

one led by the civilian
agencies, DOE, NSF, and NIST. And the other focusing on
the economic and security

implications of quantum
led by DOD, NSA, and DOE again because DOE has
a dual mission space.

So there's two subcommittees. The co-chairs of
those, as legislated,

oversee the NQI programs. But just remember,
it's the agencies

that implement R&D
funding in the US.

One of the first things we
did as an interagency and this happened before actually the law
was passed was write a strategy.

So together, we went through
the current status of the NQI,

of the quantum information
science ecosystem, and what would be
needed to enhance

US leadership in quantum. Which is ultimately what's the
goal of the National Quantum

Initiative is. And the result of that were
six high level policy thrusts.

Take a science-first approach. Given that this is still an
emerging technology, provide

the key infrastructure needed
to solve the important problems facing the field.

Invest and grow the
quantum workforce because there's a dire need
for experts from industry

and the government. Nurture the new industry that's
being created in this space as applications are
being looked for.

Balance the economic and
national security implications because quantum
right from the start

had this dual nature
because of Shor's Quantum Algorithm for Factoring. And then six, continue to
collaborate internationally

because quantum has
always been a global field and the ideas have come
really from around the world

since the beginning. Over time over the
last four years, we've augmented that strategy.

We've released a
workforce strategy, a few technical-focused
strategies on quantum networking

and quantum sensing which
helped guide investments from the agencies and
explain to Congress

what are the most important
things that we should do. How should we prioritize
what our investments are

in the different technologies.  So with those six
pillars in mind

to boil it down
into what we really mean by what we want to
do, first and foremost,

get the science right. So if you want to avoid-- when you're faced with a
lot of choices-- and quantum

is a very broad field. It spans sensors,
networks, computers, enabling technologies,
post-quantum cryptographic

schemes that are classical. The first thing you want to
do is understand the problems

that you need to solve. One of those problems is what
are the applications that would drive further investment.

And then within
those applications, what are the technical unknowns
and the engineering hurdles

that need to be jumped over
to actually realize them. So the Quantum Frontiers
Report captures

a lot of that knowledge
from the community. The agency has ran
dozens of workshops.

In the first two
years of the NQI, we put out a request
for information. We gathered all the information
and boiled the grand challenge

problems down to eight areas
where we should direct funding. And then in the individual
technologies, networking

and sensing, they're each
at very different levels of maturity. We already have examples of
sensors like quantum clocks

that are in the global
positioning system or in magnetic
resonance imagers.

And there are others
that are in the lab now that we could bring
over the finish line for biomedical
applications and so on

if we apply ourselves and
increase that level of funding. Networking is very different.

We're still trying
to understand what is the benefit of
building a large quantum network, how big should it
be, what would you use it for.

And so there you want to
focus your investment more on solving those problems rather
than trying to bring things

to market before we really
understand why we're doing it.

Enhancing competitiveness
is the second thing. So how do we both
move quickly, enable

our companies and our scientists
to answer these hard problems

as fast as possible
while at the same time protecting our investments. And if you follow
the news lately,

there's a lot of debate
over how do you protect

our intellectual property in
a world where maybe it's not as easy as it was 56 years ago.

So in that vein, we try to
listen to the community.

A little bit over
a year ago, we had most of the quantum companies
come to the White House and talk to us about what
they're worried about, what

expert controls could do to
their business, their research investments, how are issues
around talent and visas

impacting their ability
to execute their research and development plans. We also are assigned
tasks from congress.

Congress asked us to do a
research security assessment of all the programs
across the government

to make recommendations
around expert controls to various agencies.

So getting this balance right
is a big part of what we do. And it's important to
making sure that frankly

that the US benefits
from the investments that the taxpayers are
making in this field.

And the third thing is
enabling our people. So if we believe
that this is going to create a whole
bunch of new jobs,

it already is to some extent,
if we believe that technology is going to be transformative
like the information technology

revolution has, then
we need to ensure that our people are educated.

That we're attracting
people from around the world to work here. And that as many
Americans as possible

can benefit from
that investment. So we do that in
a number of ways. We encourage in work
with the agencies

to invest in
workforce development programs, so fellowships,
internships, research

experiences. We created a National Q-12
Education Partnership together with the National
Science Foundation.

This is a primarily
industry-led organization

that is committed to
bringing curricula around quantum to
all grade levels

and to making, for
example, quantum computers accessible
to high school students so that they can be
trained to participate.

We brought the US full throttle
into World Quantum Day. Two years ago, we
said, well, there's

this grassroots effort
going on to basically do outreach for World Quantum Day.

And we said we're going
to be a part of that. So we've launched a
couple of videos which you can find on our website.

And we did a lot of other-- we brought modules
to around 300 schools

this past April
14 to give people a sense of what quantum is
and the potential of it.

At the end of the day, the
most important question I get

is, well, with all
this investment, what's going to come out of it? What are they going to be
the tangible things that

are-- the technologies that
are going to benefit Americans? I already mentioned GPS
is a quantum 1.0 example.

I mentioned fault-tolerant
quantum computing as a longer term-- we strongly believe
that this will

be impactful to research
and development of drugs

and other things. But there are many
other questions we still need to solve. If you can entangle or make
a quantum network of sensors,

does that make them better? There's still some
research to do there to prove that to be true.

We know that there are
new types of sensors you can build based on quantum
information properties.

But how much better
are they than the best classical alternative? And when does that
crossover happen? And how much
engineering work do we

need to do to make that an
economically viable transition to make?

So these are the
kinds of questions that we have to continually ask,
what are the impact of quantum technologies and how do we
show that impact especially

as we look forward to the
next five years of the NQI. Just as an example, I
mentioned quantum computing.

There are many different
proposed algorithms that a quantum computer
could be useful for. But how likely they are and how
economically or scientifically

valuable they are is
still an open question. Because frankly, we don't
have very big machines yet. Our machines are at the
100 qubit noisy level.

And so if you're going
to make the perfect graph to show a senior leader, it
would be something like this.

This is just a cartoon. Don't believe anything
that's on here. But we know at the
bottom, on the left side,

that quantum computers
past a certain point are going to be extremely
interesting to scientists.

They're going to enable
scientific discovery. We've done a lot of work and
applications like cryptography

but there's still a lot
of work in the middle where we have relatively low
confidence about how good

these algorithms really be. And it's kind of analogous
to deep learning proposals

of the 80s and 90s where until
you had computers to test them on, it was really hard to prove
that these algorithms would

be any good.  That brings me to
quantum computing

and the risk side which has
to balance this optimism side.

So we know or
everything that we know about physics and
information science

tells us that if a quantum
computer of sufficient size and scale existed, it
could break the encryption

protocols we use
today to protect our financial transactions,
protect our now security

networks. So because the government has to
be conservative as we typically

have to protect information, for
example, the president's phone or secure nuclear
codes and so on,

we need to protect that
information for 25 years at minimum, if not longer. So government
crypto systems have

to be very long lived,
and conservative, and it's similar for
health and finance.

So because of that and because
the timeline, even though quantum computers might
be far away and hard to build because of that
decade-long timeline we decided

and after discussing with many
of the agencies who are leading

the new standards
for post-quantum or quantum-resistant
cryptography, that we really had to urge the movement
of the whole nation

to quantum-resistant
cryptography. That resulted in NSM 10
which really had three parts.

The second part which was
prioritize this deployment of quantum-resistant
cryptography.

But the first part was
backstopping our original goal in the NQI of to maintain
leadership in this technology,

we need to double down
on our investments in R&D. We need to increase
our investments in workforce

development and outreach. And we need to increase
our partnerships with industry and our
allies and foreign partners.

And the third part was
in between this time because even if we do
everything perfectly,

it's going to take
a decade or more to upgrade our
cryptographic systems,

we still have to invest-- we need to protect our
investments, our company's

investments, our government
investments in the technology so that's not used against us.

I mentioned a little bit
international cooperation is one of our pillars.

We've done a lot over
the last few years to increase the
connections we have with our friends and allies.

We have 10 bilateral quantum
cooperation statements now. We've hosted numerous
international dialogues

really focused on these
areas of joint interest, how do we create a
new STEM workforce

for these new industries
of the future. How do we protect our
investments multilaterally

so we don't slow anybody
down in our network but we can move forward in
a safe research environment.

And three, what
are the core values that we want to maintain as
we create these new fields.

The first thing we did was
launch the Entanglement Exchange. You can go to
entanglementexchange.org and see

a link to each country
who are participating. It's basically a clearinghouse
for opportunities

for students, postdocs,
professors to go back and forth.

We definitely want to
encourage this crosstraining. I mean, I myself did my postdoc
in England, and Australia,

and Japan. So that was an amazing-- that was an amazing experience
that has helped me now

20 years later, we want to
encourage and promote that. And this is our first step as
a body of 13 countries now,

it was 12 at the time, to
move increase our cooperation in space.

Let me just end this part with
what's going on in Congress.

The other huge thing that
happened this year that's relevant to quantum policy-wise
was the Chips and Science Act.

So the Chips Act appropriated
or funded about $50 billion plus for onshore manufacturing
of microelectronics.

Of that, about $10
billion or $11 billion is assigned to R&D. A new
national semiconductor

technology center, advanced
packaging centers, the DOD commons.

As an emerging
technology, quantum very much fits within
that definition

of new microelectronics
technology so that's a great opportunity
for investment in infrastructure

and capabilities that will
ultimately help this field. The Science Act portion which
has not been fully funded

yet had some specific bylines
augmenting the National Quantum Initiative as originally passed.

It authorized a new program
to look for applications called QUEST and authorized
the quantum networking

infrastructure program at DOE. It asked NSF to make a long-term
quantum K-12 pilot program.

So these are very positive
enhancements to the NQI that we hope to see funded
in the coming years.

Finally, as part of the
NQI advisory committee,

we met and actually it's
co-chaired by Stanford's own Kam Moler.

Thank you, Stanford, for that. We met back in May and delivered
our first draft recommendations.

Because the big thing that's
going on with the NQI, it's approaching five years. And at five years, Congress must
reauthorize the National Quantum

Initiative. So the advisory
committee has spent the last six months
developing recommendations

for enhancing it. And you can find that first
meeting results online.

And we hope to have
the report out soon. So that's the first part of my
talk which is the policy part.

The next part is going to
be talking about a deep dive into a specific agency and
actually one of the National

Quantum Centers. But maybe I can answer any
questions now if there are or we can wait till the end.
OK.

I'm going to transition
and just transition by saying quantum is more
than quantum physics.

You might look at
everything that's gone on in information
science this is just a bunch of physicists.

But that's not true. If you think about what it
takes to build a quantum computer or an entangled
quantum sensor system,

it's a lot of engineering,
computer science, [INAUDIBLE] engineering, ASIC design,
material science, you name it,

you need it to build
these new computers. And I think it's very
representative of the future

which is going to be a very
heterogeneous computing

ecosystem. If you look at what's
going on with AI, neuromorphic hardware
architectures,

and all these things are going
to be very different from what we had in the past and will
require a lot of different skill

sets. And they're all actually
very similar skill sets. Anything we invest
in quantum in terms

of building the things you
need to build these systems is going to benefit other things
like autonomy, and AI, and so

on. So this brings me to
the last part of my talk

which is LPS, my home agency. So Laboratory of
Physical Sciences was started after World War II
at the University of Maryland,

College Park. It's a joint research lab
between the University of Maryland and the
National Security Agency.

It's actually the physics
research arm of the NSA. And it was decided back then
that if the government wants

to know what's happening
in information technology, it really needs to
work, quote-unquote,

"outside the fence." It needed to work with the
top academic researchers, with industry, and it needed to
recruit scientists and engineers

who were working at that level. And so they could come back and
be consultants and say, well,

when asked when is a quantum
computer going to happen, [CHUCKLES] is it
going to happen, is this a real thing
or not, that you would have somebody within
the government who really knew

what they were talking about. At the end of the day,
that's the mission of LPS. So we have a group
of scientists here,

roughly 150-200, it
fluctuates, focused

on various aspects of
information technology, computing, networks, sensing.

In the quantum computing
space, we actually have quite a long history of
helping to create this field.

Very quickly after
Shor's Algorithm was published in '93, '94,
this is well before my time

and even before I started
my graduate school 2000,

LPS was funding workshops to try
to answer these basic questions, is quantum computing
even a real thing.

[CHUCKLES] Is it even
physically possible to build such a machine. And come 2000, they
were confident enough

to start making both internal
and external investments. So they started the internal
research group here. So we have a number of
research groups with students

and postdocs from the
University of Maryland working on aspects
of qubit technology.

And LPS started the major
external sponsored research program working with the
Army Research Office.

This was just out of necessity. If you think back to the
beginning of the computer science--

of the computer revolution
before the vacuum tube or in that transition from
the vacuum tube to solid state

transistors, very much
we're in that mode then

and arguably still
in that mode where there were many, many
different technologies proposed

as physical realizations
of this abstract thing called a quantum computer. So you really had to fund
a lot of different groups

to try to explore
what could make sense and what could not make sense.

So that's what the sponsor
research program does. It's grown even since
I made this slide. We have roughly 100
principal investigators

across many different
institutions around the world focused
on different technologies,

different qubit technologies,
semiconductor-based, superconducting-based,
atomic, molecular and ion,

optical-based qubits. Really trying to answer
these questions like what are the fundamental limits
of devices that might realize

a quantum computer and where are
we on this kind of trajectory of something that might
be one day useful.

The internal research
is very similar. It's smaller and
more focused on,

again, what are the
hard problems that need to be solved
that could disrupt

the present approaches, the
qubit technologies, and what are the material science
issues that need to be solved

to make them scalable. And it comes down to how
we think about the quantum

challenge. At the end of the day, we want
to answer the question is there

a system that you
can build that could run an algorithm like Shor's
Algorithm or a quantum chemistry

solver. And the best resource
estimates we know now

indicate that you probably need
a machine that can operate 10 to the 14 or more operations
with a probability of success

big enough that you'll
get an answer sometime. [CHUCKLES] The correct
answer sometime.

And you have to match
that logical error rate you need,
which is something like 10 to the minus
12, 10 to the minus 14

per operation to the
reality of devices. And the reality of
the devices today

is that the error rates per
operation are roughly 1% or 0.1%

so [? 3/9 ?] fidelity. We're talking about 10 orders
of magnitude difference

between the physical
devices and what's needed. The gap, the thing
that bridges that

is quantum error
correction, also proposed by Peter Shor and others, which
makes it at least conceptually

possible to build
large-scale machines at the cost of many,
many, many more qubits.

So you might need few
1,000 logical qubits do one of these algorithms.

But that becomes
millions or larger

when you include
error correction, depending on the
error rate you need, at least the
today's error rates.

So I'll just give you
a couple of examples if you're not an
aficionado of this field,

one of the most
popular approaches are superconducting qubits. These are pursued by companies
like Google, Amazon, Rigetti,

IBM. I think of them
as little washers. I mean this is not
completely accurate

but if you take a little metal
washer made out of aluminum and you make it cold,
it's a superconductor.

So if you start current
going in one direction, it'll just keep going
forever if you keep it cold. It's lossless.

And you can call that zero. You can call
counterclockwise one. And because it's a
quantum mechanical system,

it can have electrons going
left and right at the same time. And from that, you
can make the qubits.

And then you can
design two qubit gates. One of the most
popular qubits today is called the transmon qubit.

It's got nice properties for
the noise so that it can-- it's very robust.

You make it and it works. But at the end of the
day, it's a washer.

You might think of it as an
artificial atom with energy levels that you can
call 011 and so on.

So this is a little
bit dated now but these are the 50
to 100-qubit systems that you might read in
the news that people

are putting together. Another approach are
[? semiconducting ?] qubits, which are most
analogous to MOSFETs,

or the silicon transistors
that are in your computer. Here we take that transistor
down to the quantum limits, very

cold, one single
electron, and instead of using the charge as
the information carrier,

we use a spin. Spin could be up,
it can be down. That's your qubit. Because it's quantum mechanical,
it can be in a superposition.

And operations have been
sort of like an abacus. You bring the
electrons together.

Because they're
fermions, they interact with each other in a unique way
which can create entanglement. And so you can build a
quantum computer that way.

This is harder to make. You have to make
them much smaller right from the beginning. They are roughly
1,000, at least,

times smaller, maybe 10,000. We have six-dot systems now in
a few groups after really two

decades of investment. But they're now starting to
show that you can also do quantum computation this way. And there are many
other approaches

that I'm not going to
mention, photonics, ion traps.

The most important
thing to realize though, is that it's not
about the qubit. It's about building
a quantum computer.

If you think about what's needed
to build a quantum computer, there are many different layers. There's the qubits.

They need to be
good, meaning they last long enough to
do error correction,

have low error
rates to do gates. That often means hard
material science problems.

Virtually every qubit it
means hard material science problems need to be solved. The second biggest
thing is interconnect.

Qubits are analog systems. At the end of the day
they're analog devices.

To control them you need
very precise pulses.

That means that
every qubit needs to have roughly its own wire. Some qubits need 10 wires.

Which means that if you
need a million qubits, you need millions of wires
which is dramatically

different than
anything really we've built in computing to
this state of the game.

So both those things,
qubits and interconnect, they have to be in
an environment that

enables the quantumness. Typically, very cold,
20 millikelvin or so

or vacuum for ion traps. And all the classical
control electronics

which is again state of the
art because they're analog has to be within that
envelope as well.

So this is what makes it
a holistic problem where often making one
level of the stack
easy makes other layers harder.

And the greatest
example I can give is a modern processor, if you
look at the Apple M1 which

is roughly 10 billion
or so transistors, what makes this even possible.

What made it easy over the
last 60-70 years of investment. The things that made it possible
are one, digital electronics.

That you don't have to set
exactly a perfect voltage level for each transistor.

You just say, well, if it's
higher than this, it's zero. If it's lower than
that, it's one. That makes the individual
devices robust.

And two, incredibly
high MUX ratios. So if you look at the back side
of the chip, you try to count,

you get roughly 3,000
wires coming out of this computer chip that
has 16 billion transistors.

That's fundamentally different
from a quantum computer where we think
you're going to need an order the same number of
transistors of lasers, or wires,

or whatever it is
that controls them. So that's a really,
really big problem that will need to be
solved if these things are

going to scale up. So that leads us-- so that's
the nature of the problem and why we exist.
